The National Republican Club adopted overwhelmingly last night a resolution recommending that the Republican leaders of the five counties in the city "select and support capable, loyal and regular Republicans as a candidate or candidates for the office of Mayor" in the coming city primaries.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The American Federation of Labor intimated today that Secretary Stettinius, or his staff, had discriminated in favor of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in providing transportation to the San Francisco Conference under circumstances which "pose the question whether the State Department can be trusted."

WASHINGTON, April 24--Republican high tariff advocates should emulate the barons of Runnymede and refuse to give authority to any executive agency to determine tariff rates, the Ways and Means Committee was told today by Representative Bertrand W. Gearhart ...

The Equitable Life Assurance Society has sold to Henry Goelet, operator, the sixteen-story apartment house at the southeast corner of West End Avenue and Seventy-second Street, known as 260 West End Avenue.

PARIS, April 24 (AP)--A French Army expert said today he would recommend assignment of 50,000 German prisoners of war to locate and remove the hidden mines and booby traps that the retreating Germans left behind in France.

MOSCOW, April 24--The Supreme Soviet of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics met tonight in its eleventh session, the first wartime gathering with the entire land free from Axis invading forces, and the delegates, including Premier Stalin and his presidium, heard an unprecedented tribute to President Roosevelt and then rose to honor him.

If ever history has set the stage dramatically for a great event, it has done so at San Francisco. The longplanned first conference of the whole great company of the United Nations will meet today at the very moment when the victorious armies of Soviet Russia and the United States are joining forces deep in the heart of Nazi Germany, their common enemy, and the common enemy of all free people.

Alfred W. Barth, second vice president of the Chase National Bank, testified yesterday in Federal Court, where the bank is on trial on charges of having violated a Presidential order freezing foreign funds, that whenever there was doubt about any account coming under the provisions of the order, the account was immediately blocked.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24--The air in San Francisco is extraordinarily bright and clear. Some of the citizens crowded out of homes, hotels, restaurants and bars by peace-seeking but pushing invaders from all over the world remarked that there isn't room for the fog to come in.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- Senator Albert B. Chandler (D., Ky.) will be "immediately available" as baseball's new high commissioner.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee, which originates revenue legislation, said today that there was a possibility of some tax adjustments "right after V-E Day."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24--As far as can be judged on the eve of the opening of the United Nations Conference, France is going to play the game of the big powers. That is another way of saying that it now appears that the French will not take the role of the big leader of the smaller powers.
WASHIGTON, April 24 (AP)-- The House Appropriations Committee tossed some verbal brickbats and a 25 per cent budget cut at the Interior Department today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP) --Coast Guardsman Donal O'Leary today turned down an offer of a handicap in Saturday's Penn relay mile special against Swedish runner Gundar Haegg.

To its year-round collection of antiques, old-fashioned stuff and unpedigreed oddities Macy's Corner Shop has added for its summer opening today an assortment of picturesque (and expensive) summer trappings to add flavor to summer homes or inject a country note into mundane city apartments.

Gross sales of the Boeing Air-- plane Company set a new high record of $608,082,413 in 1944, an increase of $114,894,252 over the preceding year, according to the annual report signed by C.L. Egtvedt, chairman. Net profit was $5,257,522, equal to $4.86 a share for 1,082,454 shares, comparing with $4,482,870, or $4.14 a share, in 1943.

To help scholars whose careers have been interrupted by the war, the Rockefeller Foundation has adopted a program of scholarships and fellowships, Raymond B. Fosdick, president, announced yesterday in his annual report.

LONDON, April 24--Although business in today's stock markets was quiet pending publication of the budget, the tone was cheerful and gains were made by several industrials.

PARIS, April 24--Four million Germans in the Ruhr face starvation newt winter, and this is only a small facet of the staggering administrative problem facing Allied military authorities in Germany, Maj. The stock market continued yesterday to yield to the pressure of idle funds and the list pushed ahead to new high ground. Gains ranged from major fractions to 2 points, with the best marks attained in the final hour after a few flurries of profit-taking cashing revealed no organized pressure.

The net earnings of the Texas Company and its subsidiaries in the first quarter of this year, excluding European subsidiaries, were $12,215,100 after charges, taxes and reserves and provision for a special reserve of $1,000,000, equal to $1.09 a capital share, W.S.S. Rodgers, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday.

MANILA, Wednesday, April 25 --In a series of attacks Saturday and Sunday, heavy bombers of the Far Eastern Air Force blasted the Japanese naval base at Saigon, French Indo-China, sinking three large merchantmen, scoring near misses on an enemy submarine and starting fires from which smoke rose 7,000 feet.

MODENA, Italy, April 24--Following Bologna's precedent, the Committee of National Liberation here chose a Communist to head the city's government and, as in Bologna, he is approved, at least on an acting basis, by the first Allied Military Government officials.

When a musical program is given with a historical objective in view it can be a terrific bore. But when the historical peg is used as a means of selecting and performing charming music the excuse suffices for a delightful artistic experience.

CHUNGKING, China, April 24 (AP)--Chinese counter-attacks have been flung against the main column and two flanks of the determined Japanese drive through western Hunan Province, and bitter fighting raged in defense of the routes to strategic Chihkiang, United States Fourteenth Air Force offensive base, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

Six directors of The Associated Press have been re-elected for three-year terms, it was announced yesterday after tellers had completed the count of ballots cast at the annual election on Monday. The election was by proxies because of the restrictions on travel imposed by the Office of Defense Transportation.

WASHINGTON, April 24--President Truman, leaving wide gaps in his visitors' list to allow preparation for the radio address he will make tomorrow night to the opening session of the United Nations Conference at San Francisco, motored to the Naval Medical Center at Bethesda today and conferred for about an hour with Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State.

As a result of the Supreme Court's decision which ruled improper a manufacturer's use of the basing point system in formulating prices charged for products, industry probably will ask for an early Congressional clarification of the intent of the Robinson-Patman act, manufacturers stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24--Home economists of six States urged before the House Agricultural Committee today the "better diet" bill introduced by Representative Stephen Pace, Democrat, of Georgia, which, after three years would give the States $2,000,000 annually and the Federal Government $500,000 annually for research in human nutrition.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- The House Foreign Affairs Committee called on the Government today to use arms and ignore treaties if necessary to pursue any German war criminals who sought safety in neutral countries.

Construction engineers and contractors in the New York area, including military and civilian operators, were called upon yesterday to improve their standards of safety to stem increasing losses of life and production attributed largely to failure of supervision.

BOSTON, April 24--A Ruthian round trip blast by Butch Nieman in the ninth inning today ruined both a pretty fair pitching performance by Hal Gregg and Leo Durocher's disposition. The big blow, coming with two mates aboard, gave the Braves an 8-6 victory in the opener of the threegame series.

The most complete revelation yet made of the workings of New York's black markets and other factors in the maldistribution of food supply will be given at today's hearing in the Hotel Roosevelt, it was indicated last night by some of the witnesses who will testify before the House Committee to Investigate Food Shortages.

WASHINGTON, Apri1 24--Leasing surplus war plants instead of immediate sale was recommended to Congress today by Attorney General Biddle, who said this plan would give business and government an opportunity to ascertain "more realistically" the final sales price and would encourage bidding by small business concerns.

After a two-month trial, the midnight curfew that began on Feb. 26 has proved negligible as a coal-saver and as a stimulant to public morale, a survey of experiences and opinions of hotel, restaurant, tavern and night club owners indicated yesterday. The Consolidated Edison Company said its coal consumption, based on a twomonth estimate, pointed to an annual saving of three-tenths of one per cent.

David S. Meister has purchased from the Donald Holding Company the five-story garden apartment house for sixty-five families at 152 East Eighty-fourth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 25 --Two Russian Army groups seized eight more districts of Berlin yesterday and effected a junction Within the city limits. At least one-quarter of the Greater Berlin area is now firmly in Soviet hands. [London dispatches indicated one-half of the city had been seized.]

TRENTON, N.J., April 24-- Sanford Bates of Yonkers, N.Y., nationally known in the fields of social welfare and prison reform, was appointed today New Jersey Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 24-- The World Labor Congress will meet tomorrow in Oakland, with the participation of the American Federation of Labor still uncertain.

TORONTO, April 24 (Canadian Press)--Edward G. Weed, internationally known in the automotive hardware and fire extinguisher supply trades, died here today after a heart attack. His age was 69. A resident of Maplewood, N.J., he had been in Toronto to attend a directors' meeting.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24-- Secretary Stettinius stated here today that Soviet Russia had agreed to join with other sponsors of the San Francisco Conference in laying before it proposals of the Chinese Government, including one specifying that the charter provide for settlement of disputes "with due regard for principles of justice and international law."

Paul H. Mason in Bay Ridge Court yesterday afternoon charged with practicing medicine without a license.

WASHINGTON, April 24--Production chiefs of the United States, Great Britain and Canada declared in a joint statement today that the handling of industrial and consumer needs in a starving, wartorn Europe by nations still able to give material aid would develop an economy on which "a secure peace can be founded."

WASHINGTON, April 24--Lendlease and reverse lend-lease agreements between the United States and France have materially aided the prosecution of the war, Leo. T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, reported today.

LONDON, April 24 (AP)--Rocketfiring planes of the Royal Air Force blasted a double line of German motor transport streaming eastward into Berlin today, while heavy Lancaster bombers from Britain hammered enemy rail traffic headed for Denmark.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP)--The Packard Motor Car Company plant and three factories of the KelseyHayes Wheel Company were closed by strikes today, making 20,000 workers idle and curtailing war production.

WITH THE UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, in Bavaria, April 24--Swift-moving United States Third Army armored columns reached a point thirty-five miles from the Austrian frontier today and other Third Army units were within three miles of the Danube in the vicinity of Regensburg in a concerted move toward the Germans' Alpine redoubt.

A one-man show of photographs by Paul Strand opens today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. Installed in galleries on the second floor, adjacent to those in which the Rouault exhibition is being held, the photographs will remain on view through June 10. Afterward part of this large collection will be sent on tour.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24-- Imported and California liquors and cigarettes in quantities which users in the Bay area have quit dreaming about have been made available to the 2,500 or so delegates, advisers and press representatives at the United Nations Conference.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24-- Registration statements covering offerings of $31,500,000 in bonds, 7,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock and 196,307 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.

GUAM, Wednesday, April 25-- American infantrymen continued to attack Japanese fortifications in southern Okinawa and Seventh Division troops captured an important enemy position on high ground west of Ishin village, a Pacific Fleet communique disclosed today.

Mel Ott and Andy Hansen proved a winning combination at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Hartley of New Jersey.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3-- Strange as it may seem, it now appears that the old League of Nations must have a meeting and take certain steps before the new world organization can enter into being. There has been no decision yet where the meeting will take place.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Senator Radcliffe, Democrat, of Maryland, introduced in the Senate today the resolution for an amendment of the Constitution to give women equal rights. The resolution was sponsored by twenty-four Senators from eighteen States and was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

LONDON, May 3 (UP)--The "Hamburg" radio said today that Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz, new Nazi leader, had declared Prague a "hospital city" and it was assumed that the Nazis would not defend Prague, which they named a few days ago as one of two cities whose loss would mean the loss of Nazi Europe. DETROIT, May 3--The automotive industry plans to finance its own reconversion program with but little Federal aid, it was learned here today. The total applied for was $2,012,770,000. Bids ranged from 99,905 to 99,908. The average price was 99,905 or about 0.375 per cent per annum. Sixty-one per cent of the amount bid for at the low price was accepted.

OTTAWA, May 7 (AP)--The Prices Board announced today a cut of five pounds in Canada's sugar ration for the balance of 1945. The first reduction will be made in the June ration, when, instead of the usual two pounds a person, consumers will get only one pound. Similar cuts will be effective for July, August, October and December. The September and November ration will remain unchanged to allow as much as home canning as possible.

FRESNO, Calif., May 7 (A.P.)-- George Fazio, formerly of Pine Valley, N.J. won the California State open golf tournament yesterday with a fifty-four-hole total of 210. Fazio, discharged from the Navy a few months ago, now calls Los Angeles his home. Second was Sgt. Jim Ferrier of San Francisco, former Australian champion, who missed a long putt on the last hole of the third round for 211.

LONDON, May 7 (U.P.)--Viscount Lascelles, nephew of the King, and John Alexander, master of Elphinstone, nephew of the Queen, were welcomed home tonight by the royal family. Both were among "special hostage" prisoners held by the Germans who were liberated a few days ago.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 7-- Police Chief Elwood H. Patterson died of a heart attack at his home here tonight. His age was 47. He joined the force twenty-three years ago as a patrolman and was named to head the department when it was reorganized five years ago.
Samuel P. Epstein has been elected to the newly created office of executive vice president of the Bulova Watch Company, it was announced yesterday.
MADRID, May 7 (AP)--Six years after Spain's Civil War, Spaniards were notified yesterday that Gen. Francisco Franco had given them a "bill of rights."

The American Gas Association announced yesterday that it will spend about $2,000,000 over the next three years to improve methods of producing and utilizing gas for the benefit of the industry's 20,000,000 customers. The scope of the association's laboratories in Cleveland and Los Angeles will be expanded.
PARIS, May 7 (AP)--Communique 394 of Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Force:

LONDON, May 7--War correspondents' biggest headache--the censorship--has not yet been cured. A revised statement of censorship policy from London is expected to be issued Thursday, and until then every word written in this victorious capital must be passed by the censor, "for security reasons," before being transmitted across the Atlantic.

SAN DIEGO, May 7 (U.P.)--Challenger Willie Hoppe defeated Welker Cochran by 60 to 58 today, giving him a 32-point lead over the champion in their transcontinental three-cushion title match. Hoppe now has a total of 3,574 to Cochran's 3,542.

PARIS, May 7 (Netherlands News Agency)--Lieut. Gen. Jonkheer Willem Roell, former commander of the Netherlands Field Army, arrived here yesterday after having been liberated from a German camp near Constance by the French First Army. A political prisoner, he had been secretly tried before a German court-martial with a number of Netherland Army officers and other prominent Netherlanders and his name was listed as one of eight officers condemned to death.

Taverns and restaurants with bars, particularly in the Times Square area, did a New Year's Eve business when reports that Germany had surrendered unconditionally began to circulate through office buildings yesterday.

Germany's defeat, after almost six years of war, was based on a strategy of power--the industrial superiority of America.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 8--The Czechoslovak-controlled Prague radio announced today that the Germans in Prague and throughout Bohemia, a last major holdout pocket of German resistance, had accepted unconditional surrender.
LONDON, May 7 (U.P.)--Premier Stalin announced tonight the capture of Breslau, last defended bastion in Germany.
New interpretations of frilly embroidered curtains and beruffled bedroom ensembles are offered in the gaily concocted room settings on display along the decorating aisles of Macy's and Altman's.
Seven persons were killed in New York City traffic accidents last week, the same number as in the corresponding week in 1944, the Safety Bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday.

Quiet acceptance of the inevitable and a glance westward toward the Pacific were the principal reactions among service men in Government hospitals and camps in this area when they heard that General Eisenhower had received the surrender of the Germans in Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Sgt. James P. Connor of Wilmington, Del., received the personal congratulations of President Truman today for tre Invasion Day gallantry which won him the Congressional Medal of Honor.
PARIS, May 7--While the whole world awaited official word of the German surrender the Allies pressed on with operations on three fronts.
OTTAWA, May 7--All over Canada the people took this morning's unofficial announcement of Germany's surrender as a legitimate excuse for rejoicing.
Michael Rozental was co-broker in the recent sale of 343 East Thirty-third Street by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., broker.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIFTH ARMY, May 7 (U.P.)--The beams of searchlights and the red path of tracers from anti-aircraft guns streaked across the sky in noisy celebration tonight as Fifth Army troops heard from a British Broadcasting Corporation broadcast that Germany had announced surrender.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)--The Navy today announced that within the netx six months it plans to discharge some enlisted men 42 years of age or older, who request discharge, and some enlisted men who are physically qualified only for limited duty.

Donald W. Stewart, for the last four and one-half years assistant to the advertising manager of The Texas Company, has been appointed manager of the advertising division, to succeed the late Stephen M. Birch, it was announced yesterday by H.W. Dodge, vice president and general sales manager. Mr. Stewart entered the service of the company in 1936.

Miss Maria L. Daniels, who for more than thirty years until her recent retirement was director of the New York Diet Kitchen Association, died yesterday in her home, 151. East Eightieth Street, after a long illness. Her age was 81.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 7 (U.P.)-- Senator A.B. (Happy) Chandler, baseball's new commissioner, said tonight he was going to keep on with both his Senatorial and his new job "until the people protest."
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)--The Senate Commerce Committee rejected today a bill by Senator Murray, Democrat, of Montana to establish a Missouri Valley Authority.
The following dispatch from Oslo, relayed via Stockholm, is believed to be the first uncensored ...

The British Broadcasting Corporation, in a broadcast heard last night by the Blue Network of the American Broadcasting Company, said that Field Marshal Sir Bernard L. Montgomery and Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky had met yesterday for the first time at Grabow, scene of the junction of the British Second and Soviet Second White Russian Armies.

Kidder, Peabody Co. won yesterday at competitive bidding the award of a new issue of $2,500,000 of Georgia Power and Light Company's first mortgage bonds due in 1975 on a bid of 101,509 for a 3 per cent coupon. Subject to clearance by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it is expected that the bonds will be reoffered at 101.95 per cent and accrued interest.

Mrs. Richard F. Mount, president of the Girl's Vacation Fund, will give a luncheon today at the Pierre for officers and directors of the organization. Later the group will attend the semi-annual meeting in behalf of the fund, to be held at the home of Mrs. Thomas Brailsford Felder, 655 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 7--President Truman today proclaimed National Rehabilitation Week beginning June 2. He urged all citizens to get behind the effort of assisting the handicapped to become self-supporting.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Action on the posthumous award of the Congressional Medal to the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt was blocked in the House today on objection of Representative John M. Robsion, Republican, of Kentucky.

Word of Germany's unconditional surrender came on the thirtieth anniversary of the U-boat sinking of the liner Lusitania, which caused the death of 1,198 persons, including 124 Americans. She was torpedoed May 7, 1915, ten miles off Kinsale Head, Ireland, and sank in twenty minutes.
LONDON, Tuesday, May 8 (AP)--King George VI sent a message today to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, congratulating him and his armies on the "complete and crushing victory" in Europe.

Maurice Schwartz will produce and appear in three consecutive performances of I.J. Singer's "The Family Carnovsky" at the Yiddish Art Theatre, the former Public Theatre on Second Avenue and Fourth Street, beginning Saturday evening. Proceeds of the performances will go to the Yiddish Actors Fund.

Admitted assets of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company were $145,261,757 on Dec. 31, the company reported yesterday, a rise of $15,372,236 during the year. Premium writings totaled $76,484,558, compared with $77,047,108 in 1943.

Night baseball, making its earliest start here since the after-dark contests were introduced, will be presented at the Polo Grounds tonight with the high-flying Giants opposing the Reds under the floodlights at 8:45 o'clock.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., May 7 (UP)--Christine Cromwell White, daughter of James H.R. Cromwell, former Minister to Canada, has filed suit for divorce in Circuit Court here against Frederic P. White, a Navy boatswain's mate now stationed at Norfolk, Va.
The Export Managers Club's luncheon scheduled for today at the Hotel Pennsylvania has been canceled.

Blood donors at the New York unit averaged the usual number, the New York chapter of the American Red Cross announced yesterday in an appeal to donors to continue giving blood until the end of the war with Japan.
MOSCOW, May 7--More than 4,000,000 persons were systematically slaughtered in a single German concentration camp--that at Oswiecim in Poland, near Cracow ...
PHILADELPHIA, May 7--The sale of 30,000 shares of authorized but unissued common stock of the Joy Manufacturing Company, Franklin, Pa., to two affiliates--

Tonight's events: Benefit concert for the Save the Children Federation, Robert Kitain, violinist; Lily Djanel, soprano, and Robert and Gaby Casadesus, duo-pianists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; recital, Rosina Martocci, soprano, Carnegie Chamber Hall, 8:45; recital, Kate Keith Field, soprano, Times Hall, 8:30.

HAVANA, May 7--It was revealed today that eleven officers and enlisted men of the United States Arrmy Air Force were instantly killed in the crash of a heavy bomber on a mountain a, Siguanea, near Cienfuegos, Santa

LONDON, May 7 (Religious News Service, by Wireless)--The Rev. Eric H. Liddell, missionary in China for the London Missionary Society and a famous Scottish athlete and international Rugby player, died last February in a Japanese internment camp, it has just been revealed here.

ROME, May 7 (AP)--The Allied Command announced today the completion of the capitulation of the German Navy in this theatre with the surrender of twenty-two enemy craft, one small submarine and 1,300 sailors at Ancona.

GUAM, Tuesday, May 8--In an island-wide American advance on Okinawa yesterday the First Marine Division drove south to the edge of Dakeshi Village, about a mile from Naha, the capital, straightening out the line on our right flank. In the center the Seventy-seventh Army Division used flame-throwing tanks for considerable advances, while the Seventh Army Division moved forward on the left flank.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Portal to portal pay for bituminous coal miners was upheld in the Supreme Court by a 5 to 4 decision today.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 7--William C. Clark, an attorney here and former Westchester County Supervisor, died Saturday night in his home at 297 East Sidney Avenue. His age was 64.

LONDON, May 7--Although V-E Day was awaited eagerly on the stock markets today, the news from San Francisco had a depressing effect. This, coupled with post-war uncertainties and the forthcoming election, was responsible for renewed selling of gilt-edge and equity issues.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 7-- Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Carl Henry Davis of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Upham, to Robin Carl Buerki Jr., of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Buerki of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (U.P.)-- The House today passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate a resolution which would authorize the United States to join its Allies in tracking down war criminals by "all the means available in addition to treaties of extradition."

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- The Supreme Court agreed today to review an order of annulment by a lower court that the New York Telephone Company eliminate from its books certain writeups in property values. The order, issued by the Federal Communications Commission, was annulled by the United States Court of the Southern New York District. The Department of Justice in appealing the annulment, said the commission found the write-ups to be "purely fictitious."
WASHINGTON, May 7-President Truman today sent a message to all Governors of States and Territories asking for their co-operation and assuring them his "latchstring will always be out."

The Chinese Theatre, of which Pearl S. Buck, author, is president, will present a bill of three modern Chinese one-act plays at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre on May 22 and 23. Wang Yung, Chinese stage and film actor, has translated the scripts into English.

The Tokyo radio said yesterday that the Japanese-sponsored separatist regime in Annam, French Indo-China, had ecided to rename the new state "Vietnama" and to adopt yellow for the national flag. The broadcast, recorded by the Federal Communicatinos Commission, said that a "new anthem" had also been decided on at the same time.

War plants in the New York area, with few exceptions, went right on working yesterday despite the peace news. Thomas A. Murray, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, issued a statement urging workers everywhere not to regard the end of the war in Europe as a signal for festivities.

Bernard S. O'Hara, formerly on the financial staff of The Associated Press, has become associated with the public relations department of Doremus Co., it was announced yesterday by W.H. Long Jr., president of Doremus. Mr. O'Hara was secretary of the New York Financial Writers Association last year and also a member of its board of governors.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (U.P.)-- The War Department stated today that troops in Army camps in this country will celebrate briefly, when V-E Day arrives, and then return to their normal tasks.

Steel output increased last week and the adjusted index (a component of THE NEW YORK TIMES Weekly Index of Business Acitvity) rose to 151.0 from 149.5 in the preceding week. The figure for the week ended May 6, 1944, was 153.2. Ingot production totaled 1,758,340 tons, and mills operated at 96 per cent capacity.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- President Truman today signed a bill granting free mailing privileges to Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, widow of the President.
WITH THE UNITED STATES SEVENTH ARMY, Tuesday, May 8--Leopold III, King of Belgium, and his wife, Princess Rethy, have been liberated by the Seventh Army, it was announced today.

Eugene LeBaron, formerly vice president and a member of the board of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, D.C., was elected yesterday a vice president of AllAmerica Cables and Radio, Inc., an affiliate of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

LONDON, May 7 (AP)--Field Marshal Sir Bernard L. Montgomery said today that "the mighty weapon of air power has enabled us to win a great victory quickly, and secondly, to win that victory with fewer casualties than would otherwise have been the case."
The collapse of Germany vindicates the fateful decision of President Roosevelt and our military leaders, in spite of many protests, to throw our main effort into the war in Europe.

The sale of a New York Stock Exchange membership for $65,000 was announced yesterday. The price was $5,000 above that paid in the last transaction and the highest since last Dec. 4 when a seat was transferred for the same amount.

Last week's returns from "Seven Lively Arts" fell below Billy Rose's, expectations. And that's not the type of business Mr. Rose relishes. With a candor not generally encountered on Broadway, the producer said the figures showed an operational loss.

MANILA, Tuesday, May 8 (AP)-- The news of the end of the European war was received here last midnight with joy mingled with thankfulness that the full weight of the Allies' might would now be free for the final blows against Japan.

LONDON, May 7 (U.P.)--Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz's order today to all German U-boats to cease fighting affected about 150 seagoing submarines and 150 coastal types. Most of them were in Norway, in isolated French ports or still at sea.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., May 7 (AP) --Mel Ott's wrecking crew of New York Giants got the majority of thirty-eight hits, twenty-two to be exact, and registered a 17-9 victory over the Braves today in an exhibition game played before 4,500 service men at the Army Service Forces Convalescent Hospital here.

PITTSBURGH, May 7 (U.P.)--Infielder Jack Saltzgaver, who played for the New York Yankees for five years, today was purchased by the Pittsburgh Pirates from Kansas City of the American Association for an unannounced sum of money and Rookie Outfielder Bill Rodgers.

ALBANY, May 7 (AP)--Forty "war orphan" scholarships, entitling holders to $100 toward college tution and $100 a year for maintenance for four years, will be awarded in New York this year, the State Education Department announced today. The scholarships will be given on the basis of grades in required Regents examinations in June.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Spruille Braden of New York as Ambassador to Argentina.

Gen. Jiro Minami, head of Japan's new totalitarian party, said yesterday that the Japanese never had "the slightest intention of relying on the power of Germany in prosecuting this sacred war" and that "there is nothing for us to think about" following a German surrender "but how to win this war."

Hans Schaeffer, chief of the Deutsche Lufthansa in Sweden, and Johan Emil Mueller, controller of Aero-Transport, have been arrested for espionage by order of the Public Prosecutor in Stockholm, the Swedish radio said yesterday.

GUAM, Tuesday, May 8--Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz today dedicated Harmon Field, named in honor of Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon, late commander of Army Air Forces in the Pacific Ocean areas, who was reported missing on March 3 on a routine flight in the central Pacific.

WHEN the first scattered bits of paper began to flutter lazily in the air over Wall Street I was standing in Trinity Churchyard looking at the gravestone of a captain who had fought in the Revolutionary War. Like the soldiers in Europe, whose victory was at last won, he too had fought for liberty and honor and what he believed to be right.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 7-- Four thousand Germans marched up along the Swedish frontier northeast of Oslo today, and tomorrow they will give themselves up to the Swedish Army. They were directed toward the Swedish frontier four days ago, after the Swedish authorities were notified of their intention to cross the border.

Howard L. Spindler has been appointed manager of advertising and sales promotion of the American Radiator Standard Sanitary Corporation, succeeding the late Charles B. Nash, it was announced yesterday.

SAMPSON, N.Y., May 7 (AP)-- The Red Sox defeated the Sampson Naval Training Center nine by 6-3 today in an exhibition game, the Blue Jackets' home opener, before 9,000 recruits.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 7 --Sale of the Atlantic City Steel Pier, entertainment center for millions of visitors, was begun today when Frank P. Gravatt, president and sole owner, signed an agreement for the sale of all the capital ...

The business stoppage by kosher poultry retailers that was started yesterday in protest against black market wholesale prices was said to be 95 per cent effective last night by Jack Kranis, counsel to the city-wide Retail Kosher Poultry Dealers Association.

LONDON, May 7--Having surrendered unconditionally, the skeleton German Government of Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz turned to post-war problems today and--if the words of its Foreign Minister can be believed--renounced Nazi principles and began a campaign to regain Germany's eventual independence.

More than 60,000 shares of capital stock of the Sullivan Machinery Company have been surrendered by share owners and accepted for purchase by the Joy Manufacturing Company at $31.87 a share, including accrued dividend, it was announced yesterday. About 18,000 shares were not deposited under the offer of they Joy Company to acquire control of the Sullivan Company, which expired on last Friday.

The annual meeting of the United States Steel Corporation was opened yesterday at 10:30 A.M. in Hoboken, N.J., with the playing of "The Star Spangled Banner," amid the V-E Day ringing of church bells and blowing of whistles by vessels at near-by piers.

In Latin America, Colombia and Costa Rica led in declaring twoday holidays yesterday as the first United Nations countries officially to recognize the end of the war, The Associated Press said. The world's first official national celebration was at Costa Rica, where a twenty-one-gun salvo was fired and Allied diplomatic envoys spoke over the radio as crowds danced in the public squares.

CLEVELAND, May 7 (AP)--Establishment of a new Austin aviation division with headquarters here was announced today by George A. Bryant, president of the Austin Company, engineers and builders. The division will be headed by W.R. Engstrom, Austin vice president, who has been district manager in the Pacific Northwest since 1933.

In the absence of Morton G. Bogue, president of the United States Golf Association, Charles W. Littlefield, vice president of the organization, said yesterday that the war news would have no effect on golf.

PARIS, May 7--The old waiter that you liked best listened to the singing out on the Champs-Elysees and brought out a bottle. The filled his glass to the brim for himself and, gesturing toward the street, he said: "For those like Monsieur Lee, who will not return."
LONDON, May 7 (U.P.)--The Swiss radio said that Swiss air space had been violated today by British, American, French and German aircraft.

The Moscow domestic radio said yesterday that, "according to a report issued by the Rumanian Ministry of Internal Affairs," 1,280 political prisoners of the 2,770 arrested as members of the Legionnaire movement had been released. The broadcast was reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

The Socialist Labor party, which has a designation on the ballot in this State as the Industrial Government party, last night nominated Eric Hass, editor of the Weekly People, as its candidate for Mayor in this year's election. Mr. Hass was the party's candidate for the same post in 1941 and in 1944 he was the party's nominee for the United States Senate.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 7 --Haj Amin el Husseini, exiled Grand Mufti of Jerusalem, arrived in Berne this afternoon in a German plane with two members of his suite. The Mufti and his aides were deported to France. The German pilot, copilot and plane were interned.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Sixteen concerns have won the Army-Navy Production Award for Excellence in the manufacture of war materials. They are:

The Mellon Securities Corporation offered yesterday as a secondary distribution after the close of the stock markets a block of 27,659 shares of the Pittsburgh Screw and Bolt Company's common stock at 7 5/8. Concession to members of the National Association of Securities Dealers was 30 cents a share. The offering was not approved for participation by members of the New York Stock Exchange.

MANILA, May 7 (U.P.)--Philippine guerilla forces, raiding behind Japanese lines east of Manila, found five reels of motion picture film which they hoped would contain valuable information on enemy training or activity. Instead, the projector flashed on the screen five chapters of a "Junior G-Man" series.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 7 --Herbert C. Gerlach of Ossining, County Executive of Westchester for the last four years, was endorsed here this evening by executive committeemen of the county Republican organization for another term of office. His term expires at the end of this year and an election will be held in November.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 7-- George R. Bedinger of 437 West Sixth Street, who for the last five months had been employed in the credit department of the Chase National Bank in New York, died today in Muhlenburg Hospital at the age of 65.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 7 --Determined to defeat the suit filed in Albany for the invalidation of the State bill permitting tolls on two Westchester County parkways, the County Board of Supervisors voted this afternoon to retain special counsel to represent the county in the litigation.

WASHINGTON, May 7--President Truman "confidently expects" to make a radio announcement to the American people at 9 A.M. Eastern war time, tomorrow, the White House stated this evening. All official Washington was certain that he would proclaim victory in Europe.

Arthur J. Kirwan, general manager of the purchasing department of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, died last night of a heart ailment in White Plains Hospital, at the age of 48. He lived at 29 Walworth venue, Scarsdale.

The Pulitzer Prize awards announced yesterday by the trustees of Columbia University included: For a distinguished novel, to "A Bell for Adano," by John Hersey; for an original American play of the current season, to "Harvey," by Mary Chase.

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., May 7 --Lieut. Col. Phelps Newberry, Army, and Mrs. Newberry have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina Muir, to James Douglas Darling 2nd, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Alexander Darling of Philadelphia.

Harland A. Gray, associated with the Aluminum Company of America in its office at Fairfield, Conn., has purchased the property, consisting of a nine-room house on more than an acre of land, of F.E. Morgan on Chestnut Hill in Wilton, Conn. The Fairfield Land and Title Company was the broker.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Henri E. Bonvin of the Bronx of the engagement of her daughter, Jacqueline, to Capt. Stephen J. Stempien, Medical Corps, AUS, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stempien of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.
The Associated Press disclosed exclusively yesterday morning that Germany had surrendered completely and unconditionally.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Legislation to preserve the American citizenship of children born abroad to alien wives of United States service men under 21 years of age won unanimous House approval today and was sent to the Senate.

Indicative of the urgency for prompt contract settlements in the textile industry, the scheduled work session on pretermination agreements will be held today despite any official or unofficial announcement of V-E Day, it was announced yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 7 (AP) --The annual meeting of the Blue Ridge Corporation, scheduled to be held here today, was postponed, until June 11, L.E. Kilmarx, secretary of the corporation, announced. Mr. Kilmarx said new directors may "possibly" be elected at the June meeting.
BOSTON, May 7--Governor Tobin signed today a measure designed to end the unofficial censorship on books in Massachusetts.

License Commissioner Paul Moss confirmed yesterday that he had scheduled a private departmental hearing at 3 P.M. Thursday for Jacob Goldberg, an auctioneer. Goldberg was involved last winter in an inquiry by a Senate committee regarding disposal of surplus Government property.
GUAM, Tuesday, May 8--Continuing the series of strikes at Japanese airfields on the main island of Kyushu, American B-29's hit the island for the eighteenth time today.

The Coca-Cola Company, in its quarterly statement of operations covering the first three months of this year, disclosed earnings of $8,106,819 before taxes, compared with $9,478,067 for the corresponding period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 7--Within the last two years the rate of malarial infection among American troops overseas has been reduced to one-fourth of the 1943 peak, and in this country is rapidly approaching the vanishing point, the Office of War Information announced today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 7--Cheers greeted Premier Vilhelm Buhl today when he left King Christian and the first Cabinet meeting after liberation and crossed the square in front of Christiansborg Castle to pay the first official visit to his ministerial office, which he left three years ago when the Germans compelled him to retire.

HALFING, Germany, May 20-- The former physician to Rudolf Hess and to others high in the Nazi hierarchy is now mayor of this little farming community nestling in the foothills of the Bavarian Alps.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 20-- Out on Long Island Sound, Corny Shields today won the Sparkman Trophy with his International Class sloop Aileen and Charley Vanderlaan took the Hunted Trophy with his Atlantic Class Minkie off the Larchmont Yacht Club.
One of the outstanding events in the local art world this week will be the opening to the public on Wednesday of the newly installed permanent collection of Greek art at the Metropolitan Museum.

With District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn scheduled to return from California tomorrow, his friends expect announcement of his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Mayor to follow almost immediately.
The collection of red ration stamps from all persons eating meat in restaurants was urged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as a way to make rationing more fair for families who cannot afford to eat out.

MALEME, Crete, May 20--This island today presents the odd spectacle of surrendered German troops all carrying sidearms mingling with the British to whom they surrendered and whom they outnumber 21 to 1.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP)--Tiny Marino Pieretti outpitched Al Benton of the Tigers in the nightcap as the Senators gained an even break in a double-header today, winning the second game, 1 to 0, on a three-hitter after Detroit had taken the opener, 4 to 1.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP)-- Coaker Triplett's double brought home the deciding marker in the ninth inning today to give the Phillies a 7-6 victory over the Cardinals in the second game of a twin bill at Shibe Park after the Red Birds triumphed, 6--2, in the opener.

PROCESSED FOODS (canned or bottled fruits, vegetables, juices, tomatoes catsup and chili sauce)--Blue stamps H2 through M2 remain valid through June 2. Stamps N2 through S2 valid through June 30. Stamps T2 through X2 valid through July 31. Stamps Y2, Z2, Al, Bl and Cl may be used through Aug. 31.

Support of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act by the Textile Workers Union of America has been protested by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers in a letter to Emil Rieve, president of the union, made public yesterday.

Mrs. Edith Campbell Faversham, an actress and widow of William Faversham, matinee idol of forty years ago, died yesterday in the Kane Pavilion of the Home for Incurables, 183d Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 20-- speaking at the sixty-seventh Commencement of Wellesley College today, Senator Leverett Saltonstall acclaimed the leadership of Massachusetts in education and commended Capt. Mildred McAfee of the Waves, president of Wellesley on leave, for maintaining the tradition.
Activity in the security markets last week was overshadowed by the intensive drive to put across the Seventh War Loan.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20-- Horace Clark Richards, Emeritus Professor of Physics at the University of Pennsylvania, died today in the Presbyterian Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 77.

Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson yesterday urged the Army's uniformed and civilian personnel to support the Seventh War Loan and set a record that would "serve as a challenge to all public agencies and private organizations."

ROME, May 20--American officers in the Mediterranean Theatre of Operations can go through the routine of adding up their service points, but the score will not mean much since the directive received here from the War Department today makes plain that only enlisted men can expect relief from active service in large numbers.

LONDON, May 20--The organization, armament and training of the new Czechoslovak armed forces will be identical to those of the Red Army, Gen. Bohumil Bocek, Czechoslovak Chief of Staff, said today in a statement broadcast from Prague.

OSLO, Norway, May 20 (AP)-- Norwegian Government and Allied military officials have received bitter complaints from Oslo citizens against the presence of armed Germans in the capital a week after the date set for the departure of the enemy troops to concentration areas.

Although "Foolish Notion" played to receipts of $19,000 last week, the attraction goes into its last four weeks tonight. When the Philip Barry play closes at the Martin Beck on June 16 it will have received 111 performances.

Formal leases between the city and at least a dozen of the nation's major airlines for operations at the new Idlewild Airport will be signed soon, it was indicated yesterday as Mayor La Guardia announced that the general plans for runways and administration building had been approved.

MILAN, May 20--A simple financial trick devised by a Milan banker who was one of the outstanding leaders of the Partisan movement kept the Germans and Fascists from disrupting the financing of the patriots' forces, it became known today.

CHICAGO, May 20--Decreasing receipts of hogs at leading markets has resulted in lower production of lard and meat products, although the yield of lard per hog is somewhat higher than recently due to heavier weights.

CHUNGKING, China, May 20 --A second Chinese east coast port has been seized by Chinese troops in pursuit of Japanese fleeing by land and sea from the important Foochow area, the High Command announced today.

Msgr. Edward R. Gaffney, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, has been elevated by Pope Pius XII to the rank of domestic prelate with the title of Right Reverend Monsignor, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday.

Field Marshal Prince Kotohito Kan-in, a member of the Japanese Privy Council and honorary president of the Japanese Red Cross, died today after a long illness, the Japanese Domei Agency said in a broadcast recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

CALCUTTA, India, May 20--The amalgamation of the headquarters of the India-Burma theatre and the India-Burma headquarters of the Services of Supply, to be formally effected tomorrow, will mark a further stage in the reduction of American military establishments and activities in India and Southeast Asia.

PARIS, May 20--The French economy was encouraged during last week by the report of officials returning from the United States that shipments of needed raw materials and other supplies will be stepped up in the coming months.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20-- The Russians have taken a great liking to a phrase which has already caused more trouble than almost any other four words in the English language.

Twenty-four-year-old Technical Sgt. Jake William Lindsey, the one hundredth infantry man to win the Congressional Medal of Honor in this war, arrived yesterday afternoon at La Guardia Field aboard an Army transport plane from Czechoslovakia.

CHUNGKING, China, May 20 (AP).--Two junior officials of Central Trust, the Chinese Government banking agency that early in the war bought arms for Chinese armies, were under arrest today in connection with Chungking's multimillion-dollar "gold scandal."

Following an irregular trend in the previous week, cotton prices is the domestic market last week turned moderately firmer. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 1 to 9 points from the closing level of the previous week.
A double crime was committed at Ebbets Field yesterday and there were 36,176 eyewitnesses, the largest turnout in the Flatbush ball yard since those halcyon early days of 1942.

The confidential order issued byPolice Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine canceling the customary police detail inside the two horse-race tracks wholly within the city limits--Jamaica, which reopens today, and Aqueduct--was defended yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.
BROCKTON, Mass., May 20-- George E. Bolling, health authority and city chemist and bacteriologist, died today at his home here. He was 69.

MADRID, May 20 (Reuter)-- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, in a speech at Valladolid today, reaffirmed the strength of his Falangist Government, which, he said, had freed Spain from the horrors of its own civil war and the horrors of world conflict.

The Japanese Domei agency said in a broadcast, yesterday that an Allied naval task force "again is on the prowl" and "appears to be attempting to approach Kyushu," the southernmost Japanese home island.
The San Francisco Conference completed more than three weeks of work yesterday, and adjournment was still some time ahead.

Declaring that a "desperate" housing shortage exists in New York City, State Senator Louis L. Friedman of Brooklyn has appealed to Governor Dewey to include in the call for the forthcoming emergency session of the Legislature the question of authorizing Municipal Court justices to stay evictions for a year.

GUAM, May 19 (delayed)--Four American carrier fighter pilots, fresh from several months of virtually continuous operations against the Japanese, were unanimous here today in declaring that the quality of Japanese pilots had gone progressively downward.

PARIS, May 21--The present paradoxical situation in which the German General Staff, after having been decisively defeated in the field, retained control of hundreds of thousands of German soldiers in northern Germany and Denmark, will be dissolved this week, according to a well-informed civilian source associated with SHAEF.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- The Supreme Court affirmed today a decision that a Childs Restaurant Company lease of premises at 1553 Broadway, New York City, was automatically terminated when the company filed a voluntary petition for reorganization.

LONDON, May 21--Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, former Premier of the London Polish Government, told a meeting here today of the Polish Peasant party, of which he is acting chairman, he did not rule out the possibility that problems relating to the future of a free and independent Poland could find a satisfactory solution soon in an agreement of the Big Three Powers.

IT was old home week at Jamaica yesterday as the hoss players, who have had a longer hibernation than kodiak bears, came out into the sunlight after a dreary winter of inactivity. They blinked, flexed their muscles--and instinctively plunged for the mutuel windows. Habits of long standing are mighty hard to break and no homing pigeon ever flew a straighter course than the garden variety of $2 bettor.

NEWARK, N.J., May 21--The trial of Rohm Haas and I.E. du Pont de Nemours Co. and several of their officers, indicted for violation of the Sherman AntiTrust Act, entered its second week before Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney and a jury today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- The War Food Administration moved today to increase supplies of pork and lard by taking the 300-pound top limit off the weight of hogs for which support prices are maintained.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The reappointment of David E. Lilienthal as a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority was confirmed today by the Senate, with Senators McKellar and Stewart of Tennessee alone in dissent. The term is nine years. Mr. Lilienthal is chairman of the authority.
Revival of dry-era-style group gang murders was indicated yesterday when parts of three men's bodies were found in a potato sack floating off Edgewater, N. J.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21-- The little nations demonstrated at the United Nations Conference today that they did not like the voting procedure arranged for the new world organization by the Big Three at Yalta and intended to oppose it as soon as they found out what it meant.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The United States First Army, which was first across the Rhine, is "on the move" from Europe to the Pacific, the War Department announced tonight. But its journey will be by way of home and the troops will be furloughed here before they go on to battle against the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, May 21--President Truman bestowed the Congressional Medal of Honor today upon T/Sgt. Jake W. Lindsey of the Sixteenth Infantry, First Army, at an unprecedented and lustily cheering joint session of the Senate and House.

The largest proposed sale of tax-exempt securities from portfolio investments to be undertaken in connection with preparation for reinvestment of the funds in Government securities as part of the Seventh War Loan drive was announced yesterday by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP)-- Marine Sgt. William H. Genaust of Minneapolis, combat photographer who took motion pictures of the epic flag-raising on Mount Suribachi, was killed in action on Iwo Jima March 4, Marine Corps Headquarters announced tonight.
CHICAGO, May 21--Chicago's striking truck drivers tonight flatly rejected the War Labor Board's demand that they return to work tomorrow or face Government sanctions.

An explosion in the hold of a Navy attack cargo vessel when accumulated acetylene torch gases were ignited shortly before 2 P.M. yesterday caused the death of two workers and seriously injured a third in the Todd Shipyards at Dwight Street, Brooklyn.

BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, May 21 (AP)--A prize painting from Hermann Goering's art collection-- an item valued by United States Army art experts at $1,000,000-- was recovered tonight. Jan Ver Meer's seventeenth century "Christ and the Adultress" was found in the possession of Choista Gormans, Mrs. Goering's nurse.

Meat and poultry continued practically unobtainable yesterday "even in the black market," while the black market price of ham jumped 5 cents a pound, to 80 cents, Leon Wollender, executive director of the Affiliated Restaurateurs, Inc., declared.

MILAN, May 21 (AP)--Vice Premier Palmiro Togliatti, head of the Communist party, made a brief balcony appearance here today in response to shouts from a throng of fist-raising Communists estimated at 15,000.
WASHINGTON, May 21--President Truman forwarded to Congress today the annual report of the Alien Property Custodian, showing how enemy property had been utilized to give ail to the Allies in the war.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 21--Dr. Henry Seidel Canby is concluding a two-month stay here during which he delivered twelve lectures at the University of Melbourne on American literature in relation to American social and historical background.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- Two oil executives testified before a Senate committee today that they oppose the principle of foreign cartels and monopolies, but asserted that United States business must compete abroad on conditions existing there or die.

British Commando units that took part in the North African and European landings are not being demobilized, but shifted to the Japanese theatre of war, Lieut. Col. Robert Henriques, one of the organizers of the amphibious raider units, declared yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 21--Their big guns, with one lone exception, remaining as silent as they had been in the nightcap of yesterday's doubleheader in the Polo Grounds, the Giants tonight launched their first western invasion of the campaign by losing their second successive game to the Pirates, 5 to 2, while a crowd of 22,058 cheered the efforts of the Corsairs' veteran right-hander, Max Butcher.

LONDON, May 21--With the end of the war in Europe, British aircraft firms have begun to push ahead with post-war types to try to recover the leeway lost by six years of preoccupation with war production.

Heroes of the aircraft carrier Franklin, who brought their grievously scarred ship back from the inferno of the Pacific to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, will be guests of honor at the Red Cross Sports Frolics in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Friday night.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Service charges collected on long distance telephone calls by District of Columbia hotels, clubs and apartment houses were outlawed today when the Supreme Court upheld the right of the Federal Communications Commission to ban the fees.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21-- Barry Fitzgerald has been named by Paramount for the starring role in "Scruffy," in which the Irish actor will play the part of a whimsical angel who comes to earth to guide the destinies of some of his former friends.

With one week past and six to go, sales to individuals in the Seventh War Loan drive have reached 25 per cent of the $7,000,000,000 goal, Treasury Department officials announced last night.

LONDON, May 21--Syria and Lebanon today asserted their independence, which Great Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union have recognized, by breaking off negotiations with the French, who seek special rights in the two countries.

In a ceremony in the Atlas court of the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue, a steel-gray lifeboat was dedicated yesterday as a receptacle for gifts to the spring book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association.

For the announced reason that the end of the war in Europe had created new conditions on the home front that required the city's financial status to be kept "as fluid as possible," the City Council adopted yesterday, without even a gesture toward paring, the $763,213,014 city budget for 1945-46. The vote was 14 to 2.

Five million dollars in war bonds were sold yesterday to buyers also interested in getting with their securities such scarce items as nylon stockings, a table-model radio, an electric sewing machine, a vacuum cleaner and a one-room prefabricated house.

The accent was on youth in the show of summertime fashions presented yesterday by Jay Thorpe during luncheon on the Hotel St. Regis roof. Playtime clothes ranging from togs from the sports shop to dance frocks from the junior department all pointed up the young figure.

WILKES BARRE, Pa., May 21 --Operations were resumed at 326 collieries throughout the anthracite fields today, terminating a strike that started on May 1.

Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler rules the minor leagues until Jan. 12, 1946, but there are indications that his reign over the smaller loop may end at that date, The Associated Press said yesterday.

In presenting the Congressional Medal of Honor yesterday to the one hundredth infantryman to win it in this war President Truman paid a proud tribute to the man for his deed and to the nation for the man.

WASHINGTON, May 21--An increase amounting to between one and two per cent in basic steel prices, to go into effect Wednesday, was announced today by the Office of Price Administration. The increase was described as a move "designed to permit steel companies to recover some of their increases in production costs experienced since 1941."

Yank, the Army weekly, received a plaque last night from the board of trustees of Town Hall in recognition of its "superb accomplishment in the dissemination of news and information to our fighting forces." Charles Edison, former Secretary of the Navy, made the presentation at a ceremony in the Town Hall auditorium, 123 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The War and Navy Departments announced today 2,021 and 296 casualties, respectively. Also made public were the names of 396 Army personnel liberated from German prison camps. American fighter pilots who played a major role in the destruction of the vaunted German Luftwaffe now are eager to apply the same treatment to the Japanese, Lieut. Col. Francis S. Gabreski, ranking ace of the United States Eighth Air Force in the European Theatre, declared here yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey, who was assigned less than two months ago by Presiding Justice Francis Martin and his associates of the Appellate Division to dispose of 1,800 rent cases that had piled up in the emergency rent control part of the Supreme Court, announced yesterday that he had disposed of all but twenty-five cases on his calendar, resulting in the saving of many millions of dollars to commercial rent payers.

DETROIT, May 21--An offer by the Fisher brothers to buy 400,000 unissued shares of treasury stock of the Hudson Motor Car Company at its book ralue of $21.66 a share was revealed today by A. Edward Barit, president of the Hudson company, at the annual stockholders' meeting.

Herbert Adams, a founder and three times president of the National Sculpture Society, who had been its honorary president since 1933, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital, where he had been a patient for two weeks. His health had been failing for a long time. He was 87 year old.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The Second World War seems to have swept away many human conditions familiar in the past, and legions of deep-thinking killjoys are on record with the prediction that life, as we knew it, is gone forever. No more will thrift, industry...

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 21--Netherlanders by the scores of thousands lined the streets today and stood more than three hours in a drizzling rain cheering the Canadian First Army's victory parade through their capital.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 21 (AP)--An American officer who hunted through the bombed wastes of German cities for his long-lost daughter told today a story of the "Cinderella, of Leipzig" that was stranger than fiction.

Stocks moved aimlessly yesterday and as a result of profit-taking prices closed irregularly lower. Selling concentrated on the automobile and railroad shares, with Hudson Motors in the vanguard of the attack. Both the breadth of the market and trading volume dropped to the lowest point in a week, the turnover aggregating 1,000,000 shares.

Once they thought that they were marching in a great crusade, and then they discovered that they had been the dupes of shrewder and less scrupulous men. TRENTON, N.J., May 21--The refusal of Essex County's twelvemember delegation in the Assembly to give its support forced the Republican-controlled Legislature to scrap today thirteen proposed amendments to the State Constitution.

OUTSIDE UDINE, Italy, May 21--As the Yugoslav evacuation of Carinthia and Styria in Austria was reported to be progressing smoothly, a high Allied authority said today that he was strongly optimistic that the dispute over Trieste and the rest of Venezia Giulia would be settled without an armed clash.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (U.P.)-- Secretary Ickes was accused by the Aluminum Company of America today of "glaring misstatements of fact" in his recent testimony before the Senate Small Business Committee.

The grotesque slow-motion gestures of a deep-sea diver performing underwater electric welding were seen yesterday for the first time by the public as Navy divers who raised the Normandie and cleared out European and African harbors revealed some of their secrets.
OSLO, May 20 (delayed) (U.P.)-- King Haakon will return to Norway to find the country united solidly behind him and eager to give him the greatest reception ever accorded to a returning monarch.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The House Food Investigating Committee, asserting that a "crisis" was coming in the sugar supply and reporting that present allocations called for a par capita consumption in the United States Army of 220 pounds this year as against 70.8 pounds for American civilians, called today for a review and readjustment of every foreign commitment in that commodity.

Marking the first step in its post-war expansion program, Federated Department Stores has purchased the Foley Brothers Dry Goods Company, Houston, Tex., it was announced yesterday by Fred Lazarus Jr., president of the department-store group which last year had sales of $182,000,000.

Immediate publication by the United Nations War Crimes Commission of its list of war criminals and of the procedure to be used in their trials was recommended yesterday by the International Lawyers Committee on War Crimes, consisting of American and European jurists who have been studying the problems for many months.

Frank Erickson, the bookmakerturned-florist, openly flouted Commissioner of Investigation Edgar Bromberger yesterday as the city official questioned him about $22,000,000 he and his associates had deposited in two banks in the last twelve years.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, May 21 (AP) --Lauren Betty Bacall and Humphrey Bogart of the films were married shortly after noon today in the spacious hallway of the twenty-room house of the novelist, Louis. Bromfield, at near-by Malabar Farm.

When Harlem's dancing citizens come down from 135th Street--and up from Cafe Society--they usually put on a show that is fast and amiable, if not always much beyond. In the Belasco's "Blue Holiday," however, they are proving they, too, can offer an exception to the rule.

The boards of directors of the Consolidation Coal Company and the Pittsburgh Coal Company approved yesterday a plan to merge the two companies and called meetings of stockholders for July 24 to act on the plan. If the proposal is approved, Consolidation will be merged into Pittsburgh, which thereafter will be known as the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company.

Immediate introduction of a bill in Congress to avoid a lapse in daytime care of children in centers subsidized by Lanham act funds and to aid neglected children was urged yesterday by the Child Welfare League of America, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 (AP)-- Japan today mobilized 20,000,000 students on a full wartime basis, the Domei Japanese news agency reported, and began the formation of an "agrarian militia" for defense of the homeland.

PARIS, May 21--Three weeks of intensive effort have brought all but a few thousand American prisoners of war out of the Reich and the number of British and French prisoners still in Germany also has sharply decreased.

BLACKPOOL, England, May 21 --Ellen Wilkinson, chairman of the British Labor party, who recently returned from San Francisco, said today that before the Yalta conference President Roosevelt knew he would die soon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21--The conditions under which public offerings of securities up to $300,000 may be made during a twelvemonth period without filing of registration statements were laid down today by the Securities and Exchange Commission through adoption of amendments to Regulation A of the Securities Act of 1933.

ESSEN, Germany, May 21-- Alfred Krupp von Bohlen and Halbach, former ruler of the Krupp armaments empire, was evicted today by American officers from his mansion and moved into the gardener's cottage on his Essen estate.

LONDON, May 21--A new British Cabinet, in which there will be eight new senior Ministers, including three members of the inner War Cabinet, will take office within a short time unless some dramatic event postpones dissolution of the present coalition government.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Continuing its pattern of paving the way for full-scale production of essential civilian items, the War Production Board disclosed today a proposal for the manufacture of 700,000 washing machines in the last half of this year and the removal of all restrictions on the production and distribution of automotive replacement parts.
The captain and ninety-six officers and men of the bomb-and-fireravaged aircraft carrier Franklin were decorated for valor yesterday morning at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, MAY 21 (AP)-- Transportation experts said today that the Interstate Commerce Commission's freight rate decision-- althaugh a "major step" toward rate parity and uniformity--is only an initial move in a, process that will require probably a decade of adjustments.

In the chantry of St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon Miss Jaye Ernestine Dobbs, daughter of Mrs. Ernestine Dobbs of 151 East Eighty-third Street and of William H. Dobbs of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married to Lieut. Edward Henry Clay Goss, AUS, son of Mrs. John G. Rankin of Louisville, Ky. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks.

The first long home stand of the Dodgers, which had started with a victory over the Cardinals, did not end that way. Rather, getaway game under the lights at Ebbets Field last night was, from a Flatbush viewpoint, a sorry one, indeed. For the climbing Cardinals, behind Blix Donnelly, blanked the Brooks, 4--0, handing them their third straight setback.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21-- The Committee on Structure and Procedures of the Security Council ended its general debate today on the veto question, with a prospect that to satisfy the smaller nations the Big Four must take a compromise position with regard to the effectiveness of the veto in decisions on settling disputes peacefully.

There is good news from San Francisco that one of the more troublesome questions before the United Nations Conference has been settled by a formula satisfactory to all parties. This question is the relationship of regional security pacts like the Pan-American Act of Chapultepee to the general overall organization for peace which the San Francisco Conference is now creating.

ATLANTA, May 21 (AP)--William Joseph Simmons, first Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan organization, which was revived throughout the South thirty years ago, died in a hospital here on Friday. He directed the Klan in the years when it wrote a stormy chapter in the pages of American history.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 (U.P.) --The Government of Czechoslovakia asked the United States today to re-establish its legation in Prague as soon as possible.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21-- Secretary Stettinius announced this afternoon he plans to spend a day in Washington this week conferring with President Truman and his colleagues in the State Department on problems of various kinds.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21-- Formation of a special commission of the United Nations, with farreaching power to deal with a suggested seven-point program relating to European Jewry, was urged today in a memorandum submitted to the San Francisco Conference by the Agudas Israel of America and the Agudas Israel Work Organization.
The entire American line moved forward on Okinawa after some of the fiercest fighting of the whole campaign.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21-- Delegates to the United Nations Conference who, for almost a month, have been reading at breakfast time each day a four-page wirephoto edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, saw on the screen of the United Nations Theatre here tonight a newsreel showing how the paper is produced.

NEWARK, N.J., May 21-- An indictment charging Raymond Schroeder, member of the Public Service Corporation legal staff, with misconduct in office while serving as Newark's Corporation Counsel, was ordered nolle prossed today by Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan on motion of Jerome B. Litvak, assistant prosecutor of Essex County.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold the three-family building at 921 Whitlock Avenue, the Bronx, to Vincent Calvo, who plans to occupy one of the apartments. D. Houlihan Sons, Inc., and Benny Navarro were the brokers.

MANILA, Tuesday, May 22 (AP) --Maj. Gen. Clarence Martin's Thirty-first Infantry Division swept ten miles up central Mindanao Island Sunday to within one mile of Malaybalay, the capital of Bukidnon province, reaching the edge of the main airfield, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.

GUAM, Tuesday, May 22--During the black hours just before yesterday's dawn the Sixth Marine Division wrote another brilliant chapter in the corps' history. Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz made this clear today in his communique covering the bitter fighting on Okinawa.

Total resources of banks and trust companies in New York State declined from $22,052,832,600 to $21,261,311,200 during the first quarter of 1945, it was announced yesterday by State Superintendent of Banks Elliott V. Bell in a report based on the March 20 call. It was the first decrease in two years, he said.
OTTAWA, May 21--Canada will send a force of sixty ships to take part in offensive operations against Japan, it was announced today by Douglas C. Abbott, Minister of Navai Defense.

DUNKERQUE, France, May 20 (Delayed)--In the annals of World War II the name of Dunkerque will never fade, but the city itself lies dead. PHILADELPHIA, May 21--The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the MerionReserve Power Company's proposal to sell all its electric light and power properties in ten Ohio counties and certain of its public utility properties in two other Ohio counties to the Dayton Power and Light Company for $7,950,000.

CALCUTTA, India, May 22--The supply routes for American war materials being sent to China through Burma are not likely to be shifted soon. WASHINGTON, May 22--The War Production Board continued today to clear the way for gradual resumption of civilian production by revoking orders which have prohibited the manufacture of bicycles and lawn mowers and forbidden the use of iron and steel in more than a score of common household articles from fly swatters to carpet sweepers.

WASHINGTON, June 2--The National War Labor Board unanimously approved today the wage contract signed May 19 by the United Mine Workers of America and the anthracite operators. It carries for 72,000 Pennsylvania miners a wage increase of $1.37 cents a day.

CHICAGO, June 6 (AP)--Sears, Roebuck Co. reported today that gross sales in May were $77,459,811, or 5.3 per cent less than the $81,810,333 reported for May, 1944. Sales for the four months, February through May, were $316,005,247, compared with $296,007,928 for the corresponding period of 1944.
The New York Black Yankees of the Negro National League defeated the Bushwicks at Dexter Park last night, 2 to 1. A small crowd watched the home nine bow.
